Kites are flown for recreation, art or other practical uses.
Kites are tethered flying objects which fly by using aerodynamic lift, requiring wind, (or towing), for generation of airflow over the lifting surfaces.
A kite is a tethered heavier-than-air craft with wing surfaces that react against the air to create lift and drag. A kite consists of wings, tethers and anchors.

A kite is a tethered heavier-than-air craft with wing surfaces that react against the air to create lift and drag.
Kites are flown for fun, and they can be made at home.
Kites fly because the wind moves over and under the kite. The air moving over the top moves faster than the air moving under the kite.
Kite flying is a popular sport.
Kites are often flown at the beach.
A kite is traditionally characterized by a bridle and tail, a set of wings, and a line. A kite consists of wings, tether, anchors, and anchors.

A kite is a tethered heavier-than-air craft with wing surfaces that react against the air to create lift and drag. A kite consists of wings, tethers and anchors. Kites often have a bridle and tail to guide the face of the kite at the correct angle so the wind can lift it. Some kite designs don’t need a bridle; box kites can have a single attachment point. A kite may have fixed or moving anchors that can balance the kite. One technical definition is that a kite is “a collection of tether-coupled wing sets
Kites have been flown in China since ancient times.
Kites can be flown in a park.
Kites have been flown since remote antiquity, both for recreation and scientific investigation.

Kites were invented in China, where materials ideal for kite building were readily available: silk fabric for sail material; fine, high-tensile-strength silk for flying line; and resilient bamboo for a strong, lightweight framework.
The kite is flown in the sky by the wind, but it is not blown by the wind.
They are flying in the sky.
